viii Abstract Gon√ßalves, Israel. Pulsed cathodic EPD of hybrid coatings from aqueous suspensions as sealing technique of anodized AA2024. Advisors: Simone Louise Delarue Cezar Brasil, D.Sc./ Denise Souza de Freitas, Ph.D. Rio de Janeiro: School of chemistry / UFRJ, 202 3. Pulsed direct current for cathodic electrophoretic deposition (pulsed -CEPD) was studied as sealing technique of anodized AA2024 by depositing hybrid sol -gel films from aqueous suspensions. The coating was obtained using tetraethyl orthosilicate and hexadecyltrimethoxysilane as precursors and two pulse widths were used:

10 microseconds and 100 millisecon ds. For that, it was developed a low -cost automated apparatus capable of creating pulsed fields using a commercial power supply. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and focused ion beam milling techniques were utilized to evaluate the surfa ce morphology and interaction mechanisms in the interface anodic layer/film. Low voltage scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) -in-FESEM and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to evaluate the pore impregnation provided by pulsed -CEPD. The analysis of the surface‚Äôs chemical environment (Fourier -transform infrared spectroscopy ‚Äì FTIR and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy ‚Äì XPS) and electrochemical assessment (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy ‚Äì EIS) of the protection provided by th e coatings were also carried out. These analyzes were also performed on specimens sealed by the conventional hydrothermal process (HWS) . For that, XPS analyses were performed before and after immersion in NaCl 0.6 M for 168 h and EIS measurements were perf ormed every 24 hours within this period. Water contact angle (WCA) measurements evaluated the hydrophobicity of the coated surfaces. FESEM micrographs of the anodic layer sealed by pulsed -CEPD showed that the shorte r pulse provided the best films. In addit ion, they showed two interfacial interactions between the anodic layer and the film. STEM -in-FESEM images showed that the shortest pulse width provided greater pore impregnation by particles. This observation was confirmed by TEM, which demonstrated an inc omplete pore impregnation for the longer pulse. Discussion regarding result interpretations is presented based on the generation and dissipation of H 2(g) (considering the current interruption); on an alternative to the colloidal stability theory due to the presence of a pulsed field; and on the electrokinetic effects at the electrodes during pulsed -CEPD, that discusses how electroosmotic flow influences the deposition. Also, r esults demonstrated that WCAs were higher for coatings deposited by pulsed -CEPD th an continuous -CEPD and HWS. The shorter pulse width provided the most hydrophobic coating. FTIR spectra of both pulsed -CEPD specimens displayed all distinctive bands of an organically functionalized silicate structure. By EIS, since higher impedance modul us were measured for specimens prepared by pulsed -CEPD than for the continuous -CEPD and HWS ones, more efficient sealing was assumed to be achieved for pulsed deposition. An electrical equivalent circuit model and its physical meaning were proposed to corre late impedance value changes with corrosive conditions. Compared to the others, the higher resistance parameters associated with pulsed -CEPD supports its effectiveness as a sealing technique. XPS results indicated a high degree of surface coverage by pulse d-CEPD. XPS high -resolution spectra for Al, C, Si, and O obtained before and after immersion showed chemical changes in the coating.
